bboxes.raw_text:
NASHVILLE = (NPD Charles
c. Washburn. Jr., a 25-uear-old
graduate student at Syracuse Uni
versity, from Memphis, has been
appointed to the staff of the
Methodist Television Radio and
Film Commission. He will be
assistant director for the COM
mission which is located in Nash
Vile.


Washburn will work with
Nelson Price, depa rtment direc-
tor and will train ministers and
laymen in the use of radio and
television. A graduate of Ken
lucky State College, he produced
a special show in | 1868 for WNBQ-
TV in connection with the Ameri-
can Negro Emancipation Gen.
tennial Authority in Chicago.

Negro Nam ed to
TeIevision and
Radio Sfuff

Charles A. Boyle. 1884 W.
Oregon, has been named ad-
Observation-Disclosures of the Ari-
iona State Employment Service.
a division of the Employment
Security Commission of Arizona.


He succeeds James A. Rork
who died recently.


Boyle has been with the en-
ployment service since lo45.
Recently as chief Of field opera
lions and deputy director.


A native of Pennsylvania, he
is a graduate of the University
of Pennsylvania.


Boyle's activities as admins
trator-director will include his
appointment to the State APP
premiership Council, Governors
Committee on Employ-theHand-
icapped, Arizona Development
Board, Arizona commission of
Indian Affairs, and the Inter-
state Conference of Employment
Security Administrators.


He also will serve as chair
man of the Manpower Task
Group of the Arizona Emer-
gency Resources Planning pro-
gram and as director Of man
power services for state civil
defense.

New York Atty. Don M. Thomas,
a former Cleveland school
teacher. has been appointed to the
legal staff of American Airlines.


Thomas has been employed in
the American Airlines pers onnel
department since 1857. He re-
turned to the firm after COM
pleting his degree in corporate
law at Columbia University in
New York.


He is one of the first Negroes
to have position of this kind in
the nation. He is a native of Ober-
lin, Ohio and he received his
bachelors degree from Hamilton
College, Clinton, N. Y.

Former Teacher Now
AirIines Legal Stuffer

LOUISVILLE (NPD = Spokes-
men for champion Cassius Clay
and ex-heavyweight titlist Sonny
Liston have ignored the refusal
of the World Boxing Association
to sanction the rematch and said
they would 60 ahead with he
fight.


Clay and Liston, signed con-
tracts for the rematch in diff
ferent cities early last week.
The buout will be held between
Sept. Is and Oct. IL. Clay signed
in Louisville, while Liston signed
in Philadelphia.


Cities most pr ominently named
as likely sites are Louisville,
Ky. and Las Vegas, Nevada. but
the chairman of the Las Vegas
athletic commission said the
gambling capital doesn't need
the fight.

WASHINGTON Christopher
C. Scott, 81, a post office en-
ploye since 1923. will retire after
AZ years of service. Postmaster
General John A. Gronoush an
nounced.


Scott has risen to the highest
rank ever held in the postal SER
vice by a Negro and will retire
as a deputy assistant postmaster
general for transportation and
internationa service.


A former superintendent Of
outgoing mail at Los Angeles,
he has headed a staff of nearly
1000 recently.


The postal careerist was born
in Houston, Texas and educated
in the elementary schools of
Phoenix. He attended high school
in Lawrence, Kansas and studied
for two years at the university
of Southern California before
joining the post office depart
ment in Los Angeles as sub
stitute clerk.


He was promoted to his de-
partmental post in 1861 and he
is known as one of the few men
who knows all about the postal
laws and regulations book. He
became a supervisor in 1896 and
was promoted in 1912 to postal
station superintendent.


Mr.. Scott said the postal ser
vice provides a great opportunity
for advancement and public
service.

Highest Rank ing
Negro in Postal
Dept. to Retire

j. Michael (Mike) Morris. has
announced his campaign will be
vigor GUS against all other Demo-
cratic candidates seeking the
party nod for the governor s posi-
tion on the ballot.


Morris said his campaign will
contain emphasis on tax reforms,
resource developments. water
problems, and lowered utility,
water and freight rates.


He said that IA campaign is
more than fancy billboards and
high proceed advertising"

Mrs. Tommie Jewell has re-
turned from attending the grand
session of the Knights and
Daughters of Tabor held at Oak
land, Calf.


She visited her son while there
and spent some time in San Fran
cisco and Berkeley.

Mr.. and Mrs. Joe Ayers have
returned from trip to Merlin,
Texas. Mrs. Ayers drove her
three grands ons to Los Angeles
the next weekend.

A lawn party will be held at the
home of Mr.. and Mrs. Thomas
Pratt, 1908 w. Mohave, Saturday,
Aug. 8. 1t is spoons ored by one of
the Elks auxiliaries.

Daddy Bear and Katy Cerabbe is Colby Locks
older with mechanical interests is the model



Danny Verduzco Tommy Daley and Trinidad
Zamaripa.


director Jeanette Smith the voln
teer for creative dancing


Richard Mnyard recreation leader l.

highgted Coffe Lamoureaux Tues
Girls modern dance
rhythmcs Standing Ellen arder seated Vangie Esqv
Sandra Daley. and Susie Hook.


three will DID,
Thomas Little Arnie
